title: Have you ever wished That you were born in the 70s so you could live through the 80s? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was born in the 60’s. For me, growing up during the 70’s was really tough. I was born and raised in NYC and back then NYC was on the verge of bankruptcy, the streets were filthy, gangs ruled the city and crime was high. Every inch of every train in the subway was covered with graffiti and the Times Square area was filled with X-rated movie theaters, prostitutes and drugs all along the strip. Tourists were afraid to visit “The Big (Rotten) Apple” for a lot of good reasons. The city that never sleeps was a very dangerous place to be out late at night, especially if you were alone. Only back then apartments were reasonably priced and most neighbors on their blocks knew each other. It was a big city with a lot of little neighborhoods. Also Disco’s popped up all over the city, especially midtown and downtown Manhattan. Of course, there were plenty of little ones scattered throughout all the five boroughs. Then when the 80’s hit, the entire city changed, some worse but more the better. The city began to dig out of the titer of bankruptcy, only there was a recession going on throughout the nation. Many of the big companies thrived and made lots of money, but times were hard for the poor and low paid workers. It got better for the those with the higher salaries, but the middle class began to diminish. Cocaine was a new fad that quickly became rampant, but only those who could afford it did it. It became a very expensive habit, so that’s when crack was created and it was a lot cheaper. Also that’s when gay people started coming out of the closet, but that’s also when HIV/AIDS was discovered in patients and many people were pointing fingers at them for creating it since they were the first victims who contracted it. It was a new, deadly disease which was spread mostly through sex, but then they discovered people were also getting infected through blood transfusions and sharing needles. The country was in a panic and our president at the time, Ronald Reagan, refused to even speak the word “AIDS” in speeches until 1985. I really couldn’t stand Ronald Reagan. I used to call him the “Reverse Robin Hood” since it seemed he took from the poor and gave to the rich. It was his “Trickle Down Economy,” pretty much what Trump is doing, tax cuts for the rich while making everyone else struggle with money just to survive. I’m sure he idolized Reagan. The 80’s was when the world changed completely as we knew it. Computers and the internet was born. World Wide Web spread out throughout the world and trapped us in its clutches and made it our prisoner. Cell phones were invented, although very few people had them since they were so expensive and huge to carry. It would take another 15–20 years before it became the lifeline we all need to survive today. Cable tv came out, too. Before that it was unheard of to actually pay to watch tv. All you had to do was buy a tv, watching it was free. Who would be crazy enough to have to pay for it? It was almost as ridiculous as it would be to buy water out of a bottle instead of just turning on the tap and drink water for free. Trust me, the 80’s were my favorite years of my life. I was a late teen-early 20’s during that time. I was young, free, full of energy, pretty and loved to dress up and go places to have fun. To me the year “2000” was a long way to go. I didn’t realize time would fly by so fast. I didn’t realize how advanced technology would become and that I can’t quite keep up with it like most of the younger generation does. I never realized how different this world would be like, especially after that awful day, the day of infamy, a part of history we will never forget…Sept. 11, 2001. The 80’s was to me was what the turn of the millennium is for those who were born right before or soon after it is today. It’s a vast difference that is flying by even faster by the minute.

Nope. Because I was. 1972. 1989 was my final year at high school. The 80s were great and shit at the same time. And I’m from New Zealand if you don't understand some of these answers. Shit Going to schoolOur government trying to ruin our farming industryNot being allowed to drinkOur government going nuclear freeOnly 2 tv channelsOur government bringing in GSTDroughtThe cheating Aussies bowling underarm in cricketComputers being shitStrikesU2The Challenger disasterMy first hangover (age 13)Every subsequent hangoverGreat Finishing schoolDrinking anyway and being able to get away with itHeavy fuckin’ metal!High cut bathing suits (what? I was a horny teenage boy!)The fall of the Berlin wallThe Young OnesFinding dirty magazines at the dump (horny teenage boy, remember!)DrivingDriving fastGetting a holiday job and making some moneyThe first rugby world cupRugby league that was actually worth watchingDiscovering the Green Bay PackersThe Atari 2600Indoor cricketDiscovering porno movies (horny teenage boy in paradise!)The microwave ovenList is getting weird… Time to stop!

Nope, because I was born in the 70s. I was age 2 through age 11 during the 80s. I look back on it fondly because being a kid at the time, you didn’t have a whole lot of responsibilities and everything just seemed more carefree. My friends and I had fun going to the playground, going over each other’s houses to play outside or play board games inside (sometimes even a little Atari or the original Nintendo when we got older), going to the beach or amusement parks in the spring and summer… Of course not everything was rosy back then. The Cold War was still on, so we still had air raid drills in my elementary school where we’d go out into the hallway, line up against the wall and duck. I was in second grade when the Challenger disaster happened and I remember being horrified hearing about it on the news. Two years later was the disaster of that Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland. During the decade, we first heard about the deadly disease AIDS as well. But on the whole, things were pretty cool for me back then. We had some cool toys, music (well, not all of it…some of it I really couldn’t stand and still can’t to this day), movies (E.T., the Back to the Future trilogy, Goonies) and TV shows, and even technology which seems completely ancient compared to now seemed pretty cool back then (and I’m still nostalgic for it). There were times where I wished I’d been born in the 50s so I could experience the 60s or the 70s in totality (I was born in ’78 so my memories of the decade are quite sparse.. late ’79 at the earliest?). But I found the 80s pretty cool. too.

No. Why ? If anyone wanted to change the year of their birth to experience life in a certain decade I would imagine being born in the early 50's would be the choice. Imagine growing up during the glory of Hollywood, early American rock and roll, the arrival of the Beatles and the British invasion. Growing up during “duck and cover”. Getting your polio shots. Imagine actually watching John F Kennedy on live TV explaining why we needed to go to the moon ? Watching Martin Luther King live giving his I've Been to the Mountain Top speech ? Then cowering back in total horror and utter fear as you watched them assassinated before your eyes ? Why the 80's ? Imagine growing up and watching history: Vietnam growing to imaginable proportion and the massive riots in protest, wondering if you would be drafted or should join the Navy, the civil rights riots in Watts and across the US live on your TV, Woodstock, the moon landing all live on TV ? Imagine going to school everyday as your teacher tried to explain all that was going on. The 60's and 70's make the 80's a snore. Oh wait, was that the decade of big hair? Did I miss that ?

I didn’t have to. I was. The 80’s were not that great you know. Every time the news came on it was about strikes and pickets and fighting. Fashion was bloody awful. Music was sometimes ok. Hair styles were dreadful but the toys were great! Cabbage patch dolls! The 80’s were a time of being poor. Everything was either rented, like our tv, or on hire purchase like the carpet. It was when the rent man still called and the pop man came round collecting bottles and you got 10p. That was the 80’s for me.

I was born in 1958 and lived through that decade as a young man. It was a wonderful time, for the most part. Good economy, jobs to be had, no wars involving the US in the middle east. The music was amazing and some of the best rock and roll ever recorded occurred during that time. All in all, it was a great time of my life.

I was , I did, the music and technology development was astonishing, It is probably the same for every decade. Wishing for the past can be resource consuming and a waste of effort. I try to keep my feet in the present, but my heart belongs to the oast, it was forged there.

“Have you ever wished that you were born in the 70s so you could live through the 80s?” Not really, because then I would miss living through the incredible time that was the 70s! I was born in 1958, so mostly missed out on the 60s. The 70s though, were my time, particularly the late 70s & the punk rock explosion in London. But yeah, the 80s were pretty good as well ……….. just not as good as the 70s for me personally.

I was born in the 60’s, experienced the 70’s growing up. The music was the best for that decade, as well as playing outside till dark, far less technologically, just overall the best of time. Other than being bullied at school and abused at home, it is still by far my favourite part of my childhood. As for the 80’s, another decade with great music, fashion, and invention of mixing them both together. I wore the shoulder pads, leg warmers, big hair, and yes I was an adult then. I let lose, and had a totally awesome experience!

What a wonderful wish. Thanks for the a2a David Crow! My third child was born in 1974, I would be world famous for having fathered a child at THAT age! Anyway, I can’t answer this question, since by 1970 I was legally old enough to purchase alcohol. And as of this writing I’m already retired 8 years now! Said a different way, in the 80’s I was 37 and now I’m 73… Original Question: Have you ever wished That you were born in the 70s so you could live through the 80s?

I listened to a lot of 80's music as a kid, so yes. But I'm not 10 anymore, and if I was around in the 80's I would have seen people I know lose their jobs, move away and watch my area go to shit. Besides back then I would have had to buy albums or wait for my favourite song to play, now I can listen to anything from the 80's with a quick search. I know which I prefer.

No!We all life in the time which is best for the lessons we need to learn.It amuses me when I read ‘older’ people talk about the youth of to day and how bad cellphones are. 3000 year ago I think it was Sokrates also lamented about the youth of today!

I was born in 1954 (OMG!). Ever since nearly every decade seems like it would have been a great decade to get born in. I did live through the 80’s. Enjoyed them a lot! But I honestly also wish that I was born tomorrow. The future looks wonderful to me. I certainly hope you get to enjoy more of it than I know I have left.
no but that’s only cause I was born in the 60’s.

What an odd question. I was born in the 40′s, and believe it or not, I managed to live through the 80's. In fact, God willing and the Creek don't rise, I'll be living through the end of 2019, and welcoming 2020 in a couple of weeks.
I was born in the 50’s and lived through the 80’s. Maybe the question would have been “Have you ever wished you were born earlier so that you could have lived through the eighties?”
I was born in the 70s, loved living through the 80s, but now that I’m in my 40s I wish I was born in the 80s or 90s LOL Z
A2A. No. There was no need for me to wish this. I was born in January of 1970, so I therefore saw pretty much the entirety of the 1980s as a “ten-ager”, or teenager.
I WAS born in the 1970’s.
No
